summary: This document is a chain of emails from June 2020 between the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) and the FBI's New York Computer Analysis and Response Team (CART) regarding the processing and transfer of digital evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands. The emails discuss technical challenges, staffing issues, and the timeline for providing searchable data to prosecutors. This document is a chain of emails between FBI forensic examiners and Assistant U.S. Attorneys from the Southern District of New York, discussing significant logistical and technical problems in processing and reviewing electronic evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties. The correspondence details issues with data organization, missing metadata linking emails to attachments, and the challenge of managing over a million documents from numerous devices.

persons.name: M, I.
persons.role: NY CART Coordinator, Senior Forensic Examiner
persons.context: FBI forensic examiner coordinating the extraction and transfer of digital evidence from Epstein-related searches. They are the primary technical contact discussing data formats, device types, and timelines.

persons.name: M g
persons.role: FBI Senior Forensic Examiner / NY CART Coordinator
persons.context: The primary FBI forensic examiner coordinating the processing and transfer of electronic evidence from Epstein's properties, communicating with the U.S. Attorney's Office about the status and problems with the data.

events.title: Follow-up on USVI Evidence Transfer
events.description: Email inquiry from the U.S. Attorney's Office to the FBI CART team requesting an estimate for when all evidence materials from the U.S. Virgin Islands searches will be provided.

events.title: Update on Evidence Processing
events.description: FBI CART coordinator informs prosecutors that processing is ongoing, with a stumbling block being newer Mac items from the Island in APFS format, making time estimates difficult.

events.title: Request for Storage Drives
events.description: FBI CART coordinator requests drives to copy evidence onto, noting a ramp-up to 75% staffing the following week.

events.title: Transmission of Updated Item Descriptions
events.description: FBI CART coordinator sends updated descriptions of seized items, noting that many thumb drives and SD cards report serial numbers electronically.

events.title: Listing of NY Evidence Provided
events.description: FBI CART coordinator provides a listing of all evidence gathered in New York, including device types, approximate sizes, and transfer status.

events.title: 2007 Property Search
events.description: A search was conducted on one of Jeffrey Epstein's properties, resulting in the seizure of hard drives. Nine IDE hard drives found in Epstein's Manhattan apartment in 2019 were determined to be copies of three drives from this 2007 search.

events.title: Data Transfer to U.S. Attorney's Office
events.description: The FBI provided a hard drive containing Epstein search warrant materials to the U.S. Attorney's Office, but the contents were poorly organized, making it difficult to distinguish new from previously received data.

events.title: Forensic Examiner Provides Clarification
events.description: The FBI Senior Forensic Examiner provides a detailed listing and clarification of what electronic evidence has been processed and handed over for taint review from Epstein's New York apartment and island property.

locations: The Island (referring to Epstein's private island)
Virgin Islands (Epstein's island property, likely Little St. James)
keyFacts: The FBI's CART team was processing terabytes of digital evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands, including from his person upon arrest.
A significant technical challenge involved processing newer Mac items from the Island that used the APFS file system, which complicated time estimates for evidence transfer.

The U.S. Attorney's Office needed the evidence in a searchable, usable format (like for Relativity) for discovery purposes and to produce to defense counsel, which required re-processing of previously provided data.
Staffing reductions at the FBI (down to one day a week) due to external events caused significant delays in the evidence processing and transfer timeline.
The evidence included a wide range of devices: phones, tablets, loose media, cameras, DVRs, servers, laptops, and desktop computers, with one item containing over 500,000 emails.
Forensic examiners found 9 IDE hard drives in Epstein's Manhattan apartment that were copies of 3 drives seized from a July 2007 search of another Epstein property.

The U.S. Attorney's Office received over 1 million documents but faced major technical issues: emails were not linked to their attachments, and load files did not connect to native files, making review extremely difficult.
Evidence seized included numerous devices: approximately 40+ storage devices and 60+ CDs from the New York mansion, and more than 25 devices including servers from the Virgin Islands property.

The correspondence reveals significant coordination problems between the FBI and prosecutors in managing the massive volume of electronic evidence, requiring repeated requests for detailed accounting spreadsheets.
